Rafferty picks up a rock and chucks it at the tiger; it immediately stands, bristling and snarling, and the Hunch pulls back, terrified. RAFFERTY (CONT’D) Pleasant dreams. Rafferty heads off, and the Hunchback tries to stay perfe still, pressed hard against the door. It’s no good. The tiger, enraged, has begun slowly creepi towards him, hunkered down in an attack position, growlin eyes filled with bloodlust. Tension builds as the tiger creeps closer and closer... There’s a series of clicks, and the door behind the Hunch opens, sending the Hunchback toppling down to the dirt. He looks up, startled and confused, to see Victor slam th cage shut.  18.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: What’re you- how did you- Victor clacks together two pieces of metal in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Magnets. Come on, no time to lose. Victor heads off. The Hunchback stands flummoxed.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What is it now?

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: I can’t just- I can’t leave I-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You want to collect your things?

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: Well- yes-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What things? The Hunchback is at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Surely you don’t want to keep your pathetic clown costume-

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: No, but-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What do you have here? Friends? I don’t believe it. Future? An early grave, dreams? Burnt ina pile in the mud. Do not waste either of our time with further deliberation. It hits the Hunchback like a ton of bricks.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: +..You’re right.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Well of course I’m right.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: oi.  19. Barnaby is standing not far off.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What in the hell do you think you’ re-

dialogues.speaker: RUN.
dialogues.text: Victor darts off immediately. The Hunchback hesitates, an Barnaby charges; the Hunchback hits the gas just in time, Barnaby slips in the mud, crashing into the cage. The tiger snarls and slashes him across the face, knockin him down.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: AGH! Bloody hell, stop- STOP HIM!

dialogues.speaker: STOP THEM
dialogues.text: Four tumblers, still in their festive circus outfits, approach.

dialogues.speaker: TUMBLER
dialogues.text: What’s happened-

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: The Hunchback! He’s attacked me and taken the bank of the circus! Get him! The tumblers take off after Victor and The Hunchback, but Barnaby grabs one of them.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get Nathaniel.

dialogues.speaker: CAGES...
dialogues.text: Victor and the Hunchback race through the maze of animal cages, with Victor immediately hitting a dead end. The Hunchback grabs him and yanks him through a space bet the cages, leading him to-

dialogues.speaker: BIG TOP TENT
dialogues.text: The Tumblers intercept them, and the two young men are fo to rapidly duck and dodge the men. The tent is in the process of being taken down, the suppo being pulled out, the canvas rippling and falling-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Come on.  20.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: No wait-

dialogues.speaker: COLLAPSING TENT
dialogues.text: The rippling canvas world comes crashing down around them with the Hunchback and Victor sprinting through, dodging falling supports, several times nearly being crushed befo bursting out into-

dialogues.speaker: EQUIPMENT
dialogues.text: There are performers practicing their trade all over the place, and Victor and the Hunchback dodge and weave throu jugglers, a lion tamer and some practicing contortionists

dialogues.speaker: TUMBLER
dialogues.text: (lagging behind) They’ve stolen the take, that’s all our pay! A firebreather turns and blows out a huge jet of burning kerosene in their path; Victor and the Hunchback skid to avoid, but then must frantically scramble and flail to av knives hurled at them by a knife thrower. The Hunchback catches one of the knives and flings it bac the fire-breather; it shatters his bottle of kerosene, wh splashes onto the fires already burning, causing a HUGE B OF FLAME. This new inferno separates Victor and the Hunchback from their pursuers; they get back up, sprinting towards the e of the fairgrounds, the city, and freedom, when, as they’ passing a pile of weights-

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: Victor, slides in the mud, turning, and throws a running punch into Nathaniel’s face. It does NOTHING. The Hunchba twits Nathaniel’s injured wrist, and he screams in pain, releasing him. Nathaniel stands and attacks Victor, throwing wild punche

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Stop stop stop stop Victor grabs a thirty pound weight and heaves it up into Nathaniel’s ribs. There’s a crunch, and Nathaniel collaps Victor turns to run, but the Hunchback goes to Nathaniel.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: What’d you do, you broke his ribs-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Well I told him to stop.  21. The tumblers reappear, running full tilt, blocking their exit to the city. Victor takes off running again, and aft a moment’s panicked deliberation, the Hunchback follows, running

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: Victor ducks through a break in the train, and the Hunchb follows, and again they find themselves in a narrow alley cluttered with circus equipment. The tumblers follow, but where the Hunchback and Victor h to clumsily navigate around obstacles, the tumblers simpl flip and cartwheel over them, rapidly gaining. Rafferty, sitting in the Hunchback’s rail car, notices th oncoming chase. He laughs gleefully, and runs out ahead.

dialogues.speaker: THAMES
dialogues.text: The Hunchback and Victor exit the fairgrounds, the tumble nearly on top of them, running up a series of gantry’s on big bridge high over the river Thames, mostly empty at ni -..only to find that Rafferty’s beaten them there, drawin knife as he steps to block their way-

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY
dialogues.text: Where’re you going in such a hurry, love? The Hunchback turns and dives off the bridge. Victor, startled, takes a moment to pinch his nose and then follo plummeting the thirty feet down into the water. The tumblers stop, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: RAFFERTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well don’t just stand there ye idiots, after him! The tumblers are “no.” RAFFERTY (CONT’D) Bloody ‘ell! I’11 do it m’self! Rafferty turns and dives off the bridge- -but doesn’t look before he leaps, not seeing a trade boa coming out from under the bridge- -WHAM! THIRTY FEET HEADFIRST INTO THE DECK. It ain’t pret

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dyes are being poured out into the river, turning a porti of it orange, blue and green. On a rocky shore, the Hunchback emerges, coughing up water. Victor pulls himself up as well. Both young men are cover in green dye.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: I’m not in the circus.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (coughing) What?

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: I’m not in the circus. I...I’ve never been out of the circus. (beat) I’m free. I’m free, I’M FREE, I’M

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, very good, you are a very free, very green man. The Hunchback let’s out a crazy hoot of glee and starts splashing around in the water. Victor watches, indifferen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's Flat in the West End is on a street crowded with buildings. It’s entirely empty at night; one bobby stroll up the street, but as soon as he’s gone... Victor and the Hunchback come racing out of an alleyway, the door of Victor’s flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor and the Hunchback burst in. Though Victor Frankenstein appears tidy and fastidious, his apartment i window into his mind. Though it is very big, the place is a mess. Victor must h some kind of hoarding disorder, as nearly every surface i covered with medical equipment, schematics, trinkets and other assorted junk. The Hunchback looks around in wonder as Victor draws out long syringe behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: This is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Next order of business. Victor slams his body-weight into the Hunchback’s body, driving him up against a wall.  23.

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: What’re you doing, what’re-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: This will hurt. Victor plunges the needle deep into the Hunchback’s back, he gasps in pain. He begins to pull back the plunger, and see that the syringe is filling with murky yellow fluid.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told you before you’re not a hunchback, not a proper one anyway. You have an fluid pocket, probably caused by an abscess, here, beside the tenth vertebrae-

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: It hurts it hurts-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s gone untreated nearly eighteen years, but I’m convinced that if we can just drain it, and- Victor pulls out the needle, letting the Hunchback go, bu then HURLS HIMSELF SHOULDER FIRST INTO THE HUNCHBACK’S SP driving him hard back into the wall! There's a nasty wet cracking sound, and the Hunchback is suddenly fully upright, screaming in pain and then- The screams stop. The Hunchback stirs against the wall, triggering a series of sickly pops and snaps. He’s standi up straight. Awkwardly, but straight.

dialogues.speaker: I- I- I-
dialogues.text: Victor straightens himself, picking up something off the floor; it’s a very sleek, simple construction out of wire frame, jointed in several places.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Now your musculature and bones will be struggling to reset themselves-

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: I’m standing up. The Hunchback’s eyes are wide and blank.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (beat) Listen, I didn’t...I didn’t over- estimate your intelligence, did I, because-

dialogues.speaker: HUNCHBACK
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s just- I’m not in the circus, and I’m standing up.  24.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: .-..Yes, well, your musculature and bones will be struggling to reset themselves, so for the foreseeable future you'll have to wear this. I spent the day building it; it was the reason for my tardiness, I again apologize for that. He hands the Hunchback the back-brace.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I shall go to work in the basement, as I have school in the morning. Library, study and kitchen back there, your bedroom is upstairs on the right, mine on the left. There’s a water heater in the bathroom, get that green off you, and for heaven sake do something about your...Hair. Victor goes to the door to the basement, and starts to go but then turns, and speaks somewhat slowly, carefully...

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, I had- have a roommate, Igor Straussman. He’s a morphine addict, a liar and a general waste of space, who luckily is almost never home. So, should anyone question your presence here, just say that you’re Igor. Yes? The hunchback, a hunchback no longer, nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I’m Igor.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Perfect. Victor slams the door closed, leaving Igor standing in nu shock.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I have a name. I have a...library.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN
dialogues.text: 1. Igor exploring the library, running his hands over the books, taking back stacks to his room... 2. Igor sitting in the tub, washing off YEARS of caked on grime. 3. Igor cutting his hair, and shaving off his disgusting, gnarly beard.  25. Finally, Igor looks at his new self in the steamed-up bathroom mirror. He has the appropriate response.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh...wow.

dialogues.speaker: SWISH TO
dialogues.text: Igor, in his room, carefully clicking on his back brace.

dialogues.speaker: SWISH TO
dialogues.text: Igor opens his closet, finding tons of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: SWISH TO
dialogues.text: Igor, now dressed, looking spectacular, is trying his new name out in the mirror. We time lapse cut between his experimentation.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Igor. Igor. Yeegor. Eyegor. (cut) Hello, my name is Yaygor- no that’s bloody awful- (cut) Oh hello, Duchess, my name is Igor. An actor? Ha, duchess you flatter me, aS a matter of fact, I’ma doctor- He does a flourishing gesture and accidentally knocks a b of shit off the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody hell-

dialogues.speaker: SNAP TO
dialogues.text: Igor, in bed, fast asleep, surrounded by books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers, fidgeting with a crucifix, turning it around and around, end over end.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: A doctor you say. INT. BARNABY’S TRAILER Barnaby sits on his desk, nursing his bandaged face, watc through the window as doctors move Nathaniel into a carri on a stretcher. Standing nearby, fidgeting with a little metal crucifix, is Inspector RODERICK TURPIN, 40, respectable and distinguis but with a strange, harried manner; he’s fraying around t edges, and there are bags under his eyes.  26.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: A hokum doctor, ay. Always doing things you know, with the animals, es’periments and what have you-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: And what again was the exact amount of money you said was missing?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Two hundred twenty quid.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Aha, would that be your whole London take?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: It would- The door opens and ALISTAIR Oberon, 36, with an immaculat kept mustache, leans in.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Inspector Turpin, a word outside? EXT. BARNABY’S TRAILER —- CONTINUOUS It’s nearing dawn. Alistair and Turpin pow-wow, Turpin closing the door in Barnaby’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Well, he’s lying about the money.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: How do you figure?

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: When would the hunchback have taken it? The footprints from the cage only go one way, the hunchback and its accomplice had no agenda here in the circus; they wanted to get to the city. Mister Barnaby’s just trying to swindle the insurance.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Indeed. What I came to tell you was, they’ve gotten the body cleaned up off the boat, and we've got conflicted reports. Two of the tumblers are saying the hunchback threw him off the bridge, two are saying he jumped by himself.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Oh he threw him, most definitely. The differences in story can be explained by delusion, heat of the moment. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s something rather strange about all this though, don’t you think? Sinister.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: How do you figure?

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: The cage shows no signs of tampering, yet the lock had opened. The wound to the face of the Manager came from a claw, the injury to the strongman shows a super-human strength, not to mention there’s talk of the hunchback doing “science” as its primary pastime...You don’t find it somewhat ghoulish?

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: (beat, awkwardly) Inspector, I’ve been meaning to say...I, that is to say, all of us at the Yard- what happened with Claudia is a tragedy, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: ...Beg pardon-

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Your wife, Claudia; her passing was-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, what relevance does Claudia have to this?

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Well, none but-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Claudia is in Heaven. Our separation is merely temporary. What is your implication about my state of mind?

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Didn't you? Turpin smiles, seeming to realize how he was coming off.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have my daughter, my home, my job. This too shall pass, Constable.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Of course sir.  28.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: (back to business) There was an accident with a high wire girl last night. The hunchback was involved, as I understand it. Have our men question everyone in this place, see if we can find out which hospital she was taken to.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Have the artist Walsh make up pictures, and then have prints made: one hundred of the Hunchback, fifty of his accomplice, and then have them posted everywhere from Westminister to Bethnal Green.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: There is a murderous hunchback loose in London. This will not stand.

dialogues.speaker: SLAM TO
dialogues.text: Igor curled up in his bed, morning light flooding in thro the windows. He stirs.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Igor discovers a note on his door. “I- At school til 6. T £ in the tin by the door, with your key. Buy dinner. -F.” Igor discovers the tin, along with the money and his key.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: (quietly) Chisick Cross.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Igor sits at a table consulting a big map of London; we c tell by the way he mumbles to himself, his eyes darting a over, that he’s absorbing the data, easily and quickly committing it to memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor steps out, but the hustle and bustle of the busy str in daytime scares the shit out of him, and he jumps back inside. A moment later he reemerges.  29. We follow Igor as he walks up the street, in awe at every and everything.

dialogues.speaker: IN A MARKET
dialogues.text: Igor investigates every fruit, every meat, every spice. H having the time of his life. To entertain a few children, juggles some apples. They’re wowed.

dialogues.speaker: STREETS
dialogues.text: Igor walks up the street, bag of groceries under his arm. has a slightly more confident gait, now; he knows where h going and why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hospital is dank and dirty, really just one large warehouse style room filled with the sick and dying. Igor cautiously heads in, nervous, looking remarkably clean cu and pristine amongst all the filth. He starts to walk in, when he’s called out by a gruff mal nurse, dirty and frightening.

dialogues.speaker: SCARY NURSE
dialogues.text: Oi! What’re you doing here? Igor nearly cowers, like a scared animal.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- oh, I’m sorry, I’ll- I’1l go-

dialogues.speaker: SCARY NURSE
dialogues.text: You here from the medical school about buying bodies? We’ve got a few of’em pretty near to pass, I’m wagering, but- Igor notices his reflection in a pool of dank water.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- No, I’m just looking for a friend. She was an aerialist, at the circus.

dialogues.speaker: SCARY NURSE
dialogues.text: Friend. Hah. End of the line, behind the curtains. Igor smiles cautiously, still scared of the nurse, and th hurries down the row of beds, getting more and more excit as he approaches the curtained off area at the end- -The curtains pull back, revealing Lorelei, nearly unconscious in her sickbed-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Lorelei-  30. -Inspector Turpin and Constable Alistair. Igor freezes, confused.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry- I didn’t mean to- are you doctors-—

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: It’s quite all right. What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I just- I just-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: You know this girl?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- yes- no- I-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: You knew where to find her, are you with the circus?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- No, I'm- just a friend- Turpin looks to Lorelei, who clearly is in no shape to an questions, much less recognize Igor. Turpin takes a step forward, backing Igor out of the curtained area.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Hold still a beat.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- what’re you- Turpin has drawn out an artist’s depiction of Victor, and consulting it against Igor’s features.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Interesting. This girl is being questioned in connection with the rampage of the Blue Meringue Hunchback last night on the Thames.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: (horrified) The- the what-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: What did you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I didn’t- Ig- I’m Igor-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Igor what.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- I’m sorry, I have to go-  31.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: What’s the hurry?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I have to go- I have to go- Igor turns, nearly walking into a patient, rushing frantically out of the hospital. Constable Alistair pokes his head out.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Strange lad. Probably went to the circus and found himself love- struck, is what I take it. Hunted her down looking to be a benefactor, happens all the time with women like this.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe. “Igor.” Hm. OUTSIDE... Igor comes crashing out into the street, running blindly, panicked. He tries to orient himself, and comes face to f with one of the WANTED: HUNCHBACK posters. Horrified, he stumbles and trips into the street, spillin his groceries everywhere. He scrambles to pick them up, and is nearly run down by a carriage, knocking him into the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor walks up the street, mumbling angrily. He stops in front of his door, composes himself, and then goes in.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Igor, I’m- Victor stops dead. There’s a trail of mud on the floor, which he follows to find Igor sitting in his muddy clothe the fire, hunched over in a caveman-like squat unbecoming his new appearance.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Back to the mud so soon? Igor looks up at him, eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I take it you've seen the posters then. Terrible depiction of me, have my hair all wrong. I’m new to this “criminal” life, but I never suspected they’d attack my vanity.  32.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: ...They think I’m a murderer-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Well you’re not. And they’re not looking for you, are they? Igor’s confusion is obvious.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're looking for a piteous, nameless hunchback. A creature who no longer exists. I’ve seen to that, haven’t I? Igor hesitantly smiles; Victor has a way with words.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: LATER.
dialogues.text: Victor and Igor are sharing a roast duck.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course I never put much faith in the professors. Father says most of them get their job through crony- ism as is; many of them I fear are drunks, idiots, or worse, close- minded people. I find I have a terrible fear of the close minded and ignorant as they seem to do the most damage to society as a whole.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: (happy about the duck) Mhm.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Of course the curriculum is pathetically easy, laughably so; I could even laugh about it now, but to do so would expend more effort than I’m asked to expend of my studies, literally the act of saying “haha” would be more difficult than-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: So you like school then?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: ...I suppose I do.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: What brought you to the circus?  33.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (beat) The animals.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Oh, you like the animal tricks? They were always my favorite too-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Living animals are a bore. It’s the dead ones I was after.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Beg pardon?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: For parts. (in response to Igor’s confusion) I believe an explanation is in order. My interest in you did not stem from charity. (beat) I think it’s time you met my monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor leads in Igor, turning on the lights. This room is cluttered, but more purposefully than the others; there’s table in the center with several larger objects on it, covered by a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Before I met you, I was hoping to approach Mr. Barnaby about selling me some of his deceased animals.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: To what end? Study?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: No. Not study. (beat) I am of the strong belief that death can be made a temporary condition.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: But that’s im-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Improbable, yes, impossible, don’t be stupid. Very little is actually impossible. Life is temporary, why should death be any different?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: ...What’s under the sheet?  34.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: ...Life, I’ve found, is an energy. The fools would call it a spirit or a soul, but it’s an energy, an identifiable, quantifiable, reproducible energy. I’d spent every hour of my life in pursuit of this energy, and then, last year, a break through. I ama genius, and I created something that will change the world.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR

dialogues.text: The space is incredibly claustrophobic, their fall slowed impacts against both walls- For a terrifying moment Igor trapped against the monster’s bosom, but he fights free-  51. Bracing himself against the walls, Igor tries to make it the edge as the still-falling monster grabs at him- again Igor braces himself but his knees are at his chest, and t monster pulls him down further, it finally hitting the gr Igor tries to move over it; it hits him, HARD, dazing him pushing him to the edge- Gordon yanks itself towards him, caring about the flesh being sheared away, he’s doomed, i The dazed Igor is yanked out

dialogues.speaker: STABLES
dialogues.text: Igor lays there dazed, watching helplessly as Gordon begi to pull itself free, snarling and roaring in rage, one ar grabbing Igor’s leg- WHAM. A shovel comes down Gordon’s wrist, and he jerks ba his arm, taking a swing instead at VICTOR FRANKENSTEIN, wielding a shovel. Again we see the easy, serpentine way Victor can dodge; he ghosts around t huge swings from the monster’s free arm, and then brings shovel crashing down on its head- -and again- -and again and again and again AND AGAIN AND AGAIN-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Victor! It’s dead, it’s dead! Victor, covered in the creature’s blood, his hair hanging sweaty strands, hunched over and breathing hard, looks at Igor. He drops the shovel.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You killed it. You...you killed it-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Of course. (beat) I couldn't let it hurt you, could

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: Igor and Victor stare at each other, realizing with equal parts fear and enthusiasm how little each of them knows a the true nature of the other.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Clean that damn thing up. Finnegan runs up, possibly the most exercise he’s ever ha followed by his huge, fancy coach.  52. FINNEGAN (CONT’D) I’ve had my men collect your equipment from the hall, now clean that thing up and get it into the carriage, quick.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Just do it! Victor stares at him, looking completely insane, and Finn is correctly intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because you’re two mad bloody geniuses, and it would be a tremendous waste to see you hauled off to Scotland Yard. Victor looks to Igor. Igor looks to Victor. Victor offers Igor his hand, and Igor takes it. Victor pulls him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers, fidgeting with a crucifix, turning it around and around, end over end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Turpin is here with Alistair, amongst all the broken glass, as they talk to an elderly GROUNDSKEEPER. Turpin’s red-eyed, anemic condition appears slightly wors he’s distracted, not really paying attention to the Groundskeeper, instead looking up at the shattered roof, osmosing the scene, fidgeting with his cross.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
dialogues.text: We didn’t expect to have a real Inspector from the yard out, you see, we just thought there would be a few bobbies to make a report of the damages.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Inspector Turpin and I are here because he believes- we believe there might be a connection to an ongoing investigation. Turpin notices something on the wall, and gets up onto a table, trying to get a better look at the roof. He reache up and touches something on the shattered window.  53.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
dialogues.text: Oh, I nary think it’s anything so serious, probably just some hooligans out for a laugh before christma- Turpin raises his hand, which is covered in blood.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Hooligans.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
dialogues.text: Good christ-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Constable, give me a lift would you?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROOF...
dialogues.text: Turpin has pulled himself up out onto the shattered roof, Constable Alistair clumsily following. Turpin begins maki his way further up the roof.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Inspector, I don’t think it’s safe that we should-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Oh come now, I’m making easy work of it, and I haven’t slept in days.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: ...-You haven’t been sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: A slip of the tongue. It’s just been a difficult time. Not enough money in this job; a christly occupation, to be certain, but I can’t afford a sitter to watch my Rebecca, and it’s...taxing, on the mind. I’ve been having nightmares, as well.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Well, the case has gone mostly cold. Sir, if you need a break, I’m sure myself or Inspector Walton could take over- Turpin hoists himself up onto the next level of the roof, noticing Igor’s shoe and picking it up as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly, Ali; what do you think the nightmares are...about...

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Inspector? Something wrong?  54. Alistair hurriedly pulls himself up onto the roof after Turpin, and sees Turpin, still clutching the shoe, starin the glaringly obvious trail of blood and destruction, biz and horrifying in the darkening daylight.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dear god.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: ..+-Mostly cold indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor and Igor are arguing; it’s the first time this has ever happened.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: It was bloody homicidal!

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: There was no way I could’ve known-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: But Victor you could’ve helped, you could've done something-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I did do something, I saved your life! What was I meant to do, spring up like a jack-in-the-box after it pummeled me into a wall, say how-ya-do and take it down with a crisp uppercut? What did you want—

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: You said you didn’t care about the people at the school! The other students-—

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Stop going on about “people” being “in danger” and you being “thrown off a building,” Igor, we made real progress today! Finnegan emerges from the attic door. Igor starts a rebuttal, but Victor raises a hand, and Igor’s subservien instincts guide him to silence. They look to Finnegan.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Am I to understand you...built all that?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: That’s correct.  55.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: And you...Mr. Straussman, you were responsible for conglomerating the organic tissue of the creature I saw today?

dialogues.speaker: I-
dialogues.text: (looks to Victor) Yes, that’s right. Finnegan's next words are measured to the millimeter.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: I...apologize, Victor. I had...misjudged you. Your flaws, though they are glaring and massive are...merely social, not intellectual. I find your work astonishing, innovative, and...to be perfectly frank...brilliant beyond my own ability to comprehend. There’s a beat, and Finnegan takes a deep breath. FINNEGAN (CONT’D) As you know, I come from the third richest family in England. Could you create another one, like Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Like Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Well, no. Aman. Something capable of following orders.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: No, that’s ridicu-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: We'll do it. We can do it.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Is there a hesitation, Igor?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: This technology is not meant for-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: There is no hesitation. Finnegan gives Igor a short glance, chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: I have the means to back you in your experiments on much larger scale. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All of them, Igor, this artificial man would just be a starting point. You're certain you’re-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: He’s certain.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Hah, very well. I’11 want another demonstration, more controlled. I want to know that you can follow direction. Take orders, so to speak. Is this a problem?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Excellent. Expect to hear from me soon. Finnegan leaves, and Igor stares angrily at Victor. Victo turns on him abruptly, and before Igor can speak he’s immediately caught in a paralyzingly crisp stream of word

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You did not create this technology, yet you presume to tell me how to use it? Know your place. I will not let your own ignorance of the world at large stand in the way of the progress of my experiments.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: But Victor, surely-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Have you already forgotten what I did for you at the circus? Igor falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is my destiny, this is your destiny, Finnegan is our only ally and we will build him a whole damn zoo of homunculi if it means furthering our research, am I understood?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: +..Yes Mast- Yes Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor slowly comes down the stairs. Victor, wearing a lab- coat, is working in near total darkness, lit by sparks.  57. He’s standing over the operating table, which has a new s over it; something under the sheet writhes and twists bizarrely.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: So glad you could be here. I want to show you my newest creation. Igor moves forward; there’s strange, muted growling from beneath the sheet. Igor looks to Victor, who grabs the sh and yanks it off, revealing... The Hunchback, dirty in his tattered clown uniform, writh in his restraints on the table! The Hunchback turns to Igor and let’s out Gordon’s hideou mechanical scream!

dialogues.speaker: SMASH TO
dialogues.text: INT. VICTOR'S FLAT - IGOR’S ROOM Igor snaps awake in bed, breathing hard. He calms himself down, and then looks out the window, at dawn over London. EXT. BARON BOMINE’S RESIDENCE - MORNING The huge house is beautiful, led into by a long driveway. Igor stands at the edge of this drive, clearly nervous, fidgeting. A butler comes walking up the drive to get the mail, and Igor, frantic, jumps into a bush to try to hide The butler reaches the end of the drive, picks up the mai and then casually turns to Igor in the bush.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I...uh...I’m here to see Lorelei.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Master Igor, I presume. Igor falters, surprised, and then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor and Lorelei, looking positively scorching hot, walk together up a walkway on the side of the Thames.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: Well why don’t you just tell him you won't do it?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It’s not- I owe him everything, I can’t just-  58.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: Why not? You said he identifies you as his partner.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes...

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: I don’t know, if you ask me the whole business sounds sinister. Cutting up corpses? Bringing people back from the grave? I’m not a scientist nor a priest, but doesn’t it seem wrong to you? Against nature?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: No, no...It’s about life, not death. Igor and Lorelei are coming up a bridge to cross it, and realizes privately that it’s the same bridge he jumped of his circus escape. They stop, looking out over the dyes.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Victor dreams of a world filled with hope, instead of fear. A world where a mother who dies during childbirth can live to see her son, where a murdered man can personally identify his murderer. Where a paralyzed soldier with shrapnel embedded in his spine can be killed, healed, and then be brought back to life to walk again. The possibilities are endless...

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: Yes but Igor...what do you want? What is your place in this dream?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: ...-Enough about me. What’s next for you? Lorelei gives him a look, but then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: Honestly? I was thinking of starting to give lessons...maybe even starting a school.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Trapeze?

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: No, very few high society girls enjoy...trapeze, more dance. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gymnastics and dance, all the things I know best- I could never go back to a circus, to that life- Lorelei stops, seeming to gather herself.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I must- I must- you were my closest friend, for three years I knew you as “the hunchback-”

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: That’s over now-

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: But the things I saw and- Igor can you ever forgive me, I’m so sorry-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: You shouldn't apologize-

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: No, I should. I should I should (is overcome) I saw the way they treated you, sleeping in that rail car and-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Lorelei-

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: The beatings, you’d come around covered in bruises, I did nothing oh I did nothing, because I was too afraid and, and selfish-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Lorelei it’s all right-

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: But that’s your nature to say “it’s all right,” you’re too forgiving-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: What were you going to do? Take it up with management? Who was there to tell? Who was there to turn to? If you’d come to my aid Nathaniel, Rafferty and the rest...I never blamed you. Not once. Ever. Igor let’s this sink in. They look down over bridge, to where the dyes are pouring into the water, coloring it purple, blue, red, green...

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides, we’re here now, aren’t we? We're here and we’re beautiful.  60.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: (collecting herself) What I’m saying is you mustn’t allow anyone to bully you, ever again. If you think Victor is on the wrong road, you must make a stand. Don’t let yourself be anyone’s footstool, ever again. Promise me. Igor blinks; he’s somewhat in shock.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I...I promise. There’s a beat. They’re staring into each other's eyes. There should be a kiss here. There isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor is confidently approaching the door; he reaches out open it, but then takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: (mutter under his breath) Victor...truly respect me as a scientist...something you can’t control... Someone loudly clears their throat behind him, startling into a little yelp. There stands Doctor Claus Von FRANKENSTEIN, late 50s earl 60s, lean and gray, with a demeanor so cold his breath ha wind chill factor.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Igor. You look...slimmer. I see you've finally organized your hair. (beat) You know your parents are worried sick about you, I assume. Tina has been in regular correspondence.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: .«.-I’m sorry, I don’t-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Is Victor here.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Yes, I-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Very well.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor sits at his desk; he’s engrossed in drawing someth a blueprint. He’s fully absorbed in it, and doesn’t look when Igor enters.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Do you really think it’s wise that you go gallivanting about on the town when there’s a manhunt-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Victor.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I’m busy- father!? Victor jumps up in such boyish haste he nearly knocks ove his work table.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You- you came for Christmas-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: No, Victor. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I- yes, of course, please.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: (to Igor) Leave. Igor looks to Victor; shit, there goes his chance to conf him. He goes up the stairs, but then stops at the top, surreptitiously eavesdropping as Victor and his father si the fire.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Father, I’m so excited to tell you, I’ve had great breakthroughs with my experiments— Frankenstein talks into the fire, never once addressing Victor; throughout their discussion Victor leans further further forward in his chair, trying to force himself int his father’s eye-line.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: My theories- listen father, my theories, they were all correct-  62.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: I don’t care about your disastrous experiments or your poorly researched theories-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Haha, yes, but that’s what I’m-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Victor, silence. Victor falls quiet, the smile dripping off of his face. FRANKENSTEIN (CONT’D) When you were smaller I always had a great anxiety about you. Your mother and myself always saw that you had a capacity to ruin things. Do you remember all the things you ruined.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Do you recall what I said about your experiments.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: I said your experiments were of ill repute. I told you not to become a doctor. The modern doctor is a wasteful man, I said, many times. He cannot accept that death is the inevitable, inescapable conclusion of life. He tries to “beat the reaper.” This is futile. I have told you this many thousands of times throughout your childhood, as it is a lesson, as you know, that cost me a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: But- you see that’s what I wanted to tell you, I’ve done it- I mean I can show you, I’ve finally... Claus stares at Victor. Victor freezes in the gaze of the one person he clearly most wants to impress...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Yesterday I received a telegram, informing me that you are to be called before the board of directors of the college. They say you neglect schoolwork. They say you behave strangely. They intend to expel you. Did you know this?  63.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I- expel me, they can’t-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Can’t they?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: ...Father...if you just listen to me, I...I...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Luckily you are of age where I no longer need to take responsibility for your faults and failings. If the board asks me to speak in your hearing, I will tell them you never should have been admitted in the first place. Victor sits staring at his father.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I...I’m so sorry father.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Apologies. Are. Meaningless. How many times must I tell you. Frankenstein stands up and leaves, just like that, leavin Victor sitting, silent. Igor, upstairs, clearly doesn’t k what to do next. INT. SCOTLAND YARD - TURPIN’S OFFICE Turpin’s office is messy, clearly the den of a hardworkin man. He’s sitting at the desk alongside his daughter REBECCA, 9 years old. She’s adorable, currently playing w Turpin’s magnifying glass. He leans to and makes a face at her through it. She laugh delighted. Alistair enters, holding a sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Results on the shoe are back, Inspector- oh, hello Miss Rebecca-

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (peering at him through the magnifier) Hello Mister Alistair.  64.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I couldn't find a sitter. Busy night. Let me see. Turpin grabs the list, going over it.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Custom job, like you thought. Tailor made by Red Crescent Cobblers, only six made in that size in the last two years-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Ha. Well would you look at that. (flips the list over) “Igor.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting. Victor is staring at it through his window. He’s a million miles away, lost in the labyrinth his own brain, mumbling to himself.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: So what’s this then? Victor's startled; he turns to see Igor holding the bluep he was working on.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Finnegan's project. An artificial man, a modern Prometheus-...it’s stupid. The research is pointless. Igor looks at Victor; he’s pathetic, sitting there like a child. His father’s words split him down the middle. Igor seems to steel himself... ..-but then stops, his own kindheartedness winning out.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: It’s also not big enough.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: ..-what-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Oh nothing, never mind-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: No, I- what do you mean? Igor turns the blueprint around; it’s a human body, or rather, instructions for building one.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Gordon was fast, sure...but he couldn’t muster much strength at all. Seemed to be having a hard time breathing-  Victor perks up just a tiny bit.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Embolisms, in the lungs, of course! With that much raw energy coursing through the body the organs overtaxed themselves, would’ve been dead in ten minutes shovel or no!

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: But if we’re going to build something that we want to live and stay alive, we’re going to need more energy. Tons more energy.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes. But what could possibly generate-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR VICTOR
dialogues.text: Lightning? Lightning! Victor sits up scrambling through his messy desk.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have just the thing- one of my earliest designs for the Lazarus sucked energy out of the air, surely a larger version could, create a static burst similar to lightning, or, in theory- 65. He finds the blueprint he was looking for; a menacing spi mad science rig labelled “The Cloud Hook.”

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How would it handle the energy- I mean we can’t simply make bigger organs-—

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Two sets of lungs.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Ha! Aha! Yes, brilliant! Not just lungs, either, two hearts, as well, keep the blood flowing through that bigger body!

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Shall I get some whiskey-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes! Do that!

dialogues.speaker: ROOM, LATER...
dialogues.text: Victor has pulled a chalkboard into the living room. The two of them are drinking, laughing, diagramming their creatio  66.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: He’1ll need a broad head- maybe an elephant skull-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, to house all the electrical stabilizing equipment- maybe we could just make our own skull-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Make our own- LATER... Drunker.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The bones will have to be reenforced; we can shape elk, maybe-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: And we can give him a great...great flat head-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Yes, and then, install, a chess board across the top of his head-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes so that I shall beat you at chess whilst riding on the shoulders of my glorious behemoth- LATER... Drunkest. Igor holding himself up on the board, Victor perched awkwardly in the chair, both of them unable to ta or breathe through laughter.

dialogues.speaker: SADDLES TO RIDE ON THE- BREASTS-
dialogues.text: GIANT BREASTS AND PEOPLE WILL say “here come Igor and Victor and their masterpiece of tits”-

dialogues.speaker: SLAM TO
dialogues.text: Igor, fast asleep on the floor of his bedroom. There's noises from downstairs. Igor, shoeless and bedraggled, checks the clock: 3:46 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor cautiously makes his way down the stairs, seeing Vic fully dressed, headed out the door.  67.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re awake. I didn’t want to disturb you. Finnegan’s called us in for our second test.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: What? Now?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, apparently it’s quite urgent.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Well let me-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Igor, there’s no time. Victor turns and starts to head out the door.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: But I don’t even- wait! Victor!

dialogues.speaker: SMASH TO
dialogues.text: Igor, still shoeless, in a carriage next to Victor as it through the streets. He looks understandably pensive. INT. DETTWEILER’S LAB It’s a big warehouse space; all the lights are out, excep for a few at the back, which faintly illuminate moving figures. Igor and Victor enter at the darkened side, and bright wh electrical bulbs flicker to life, revealing a pristinely clean, high tech laboratory and machine shop. Over at the far end, we can see Finnegan, standing around table with a bunch of well-appointed men in labcoats.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Excellent! You made it. This way, right this way. Finnegan beckons them, and Victor starts quickly moving through the lab, Igor behind him, amazed by all the diffe equipment. They approach the crowd of scientists, and Finnegan smile they're gathered around a little dirty bundle on the tabl FINNEGAN (CONT’D) So glad you could make it. This is Fritz Dettweiler, the man I told you about, Victor. Fritz, this is Victor Frankenstein, Igor Straussman.  68. Igor awkwardly extends a hand to Fritz DETTWEILER, late 4 a gaunt, wispy German man with the countenance of a skele He glances at Igor’s outstretched hand, disinterested.

dialogues.speaker: DETTWEILER
dialogues.text: I do not normally work with a partner, much less two. Young Finnegan reached me through his father’s company. He has told me you young men can do things, wondrous things with flesh. Perhaps too wondrous to be believed.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Dettweiler’s an engineer.

dialogues.speaker: DETTWEILER
dialogues.text: The foremost engineer in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: That seems a bit of a reach.

dialogues.speaker: DETTWEILER
dialogues.text: As does the ability to reanimate the dead. Victor just smiles. Dettweiler sighs.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Here, you'll see, you'll see... Finnegan goes around the table to the bundle, and unwraps Igor and Victor leaning in. It’s...he is a dead infant, n even a year old. Its little body is cold and gray, but no gruesome. FINNEGAN (CONT’D) Dead not even six hours. Igor pulls back in revulsion, whilst Victor merely looks Finnegan.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: One of my work-studies. I very charitably decided to work Christmas Eve, and lo and behold, the Baby Winthrop passed on.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: The parents?

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Lower class people; the Winthrops, of Devonshire road. I’ve told them I’ve taken the baby to the mortuary.  69. Dettweiler raises a marble.

dialogues.speaker: DETTWEILER
dialogues.text: This was found in the infant’s throat. They should have watched their child with more care. Dettweiler smiles at Igor, who cringes.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: We've got a private room in there set up with all the equipment from the blueprints you gave me.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: You gave him your plans? Victor, ignoring Igor, nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: DETTWEILER
dialogues.text: So. Can you do it?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Absolutely. INT. DETTWEILER’S LAB - PRE-OP Victor and Igor are washing up.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Tell me it will work. Tell me the baby will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Of course it will work. The bio- electric energy from the fork should heal any of the cells lost from the subject’s period of death--

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Victor, we don’t know if-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I do. (beat) I’ve resurrected rats before, and they came out...you know, mostly alright, and that was before I had your gifted hands. You can save a life or let it disappear.

dialogues.speaker: SOLEMN SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Victor and Igor, in a private room cramped with sleeker, high tech versions of Victor’s equipment, lay the Baby Winthrop on the table, and begin the process of prepping  70. We watch as they give it various injections, stretch the to hold off rigor mortis, as Igor uses his deft skills as surgeon to insert electrodes all over the body. Igor attaches the Lazarus Fork bolts into the baby’s neck Finnegan, Dettweiler and his scientists surround the tabl Igor stands back, nervous. Victor primes the machines, and without ceremony, fires t dynamos. Nothing happens, and then the electrical wiring all over baby lights on fire. This gets laughs from the scientists

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Igor, help, quickly- Igor and Victor tear away all the equipment, putting out fires... ...to reveal the Baby Winthrop, uninjured and very much alive. Finnegan looks to Dettweiler, enormously pleased w himself; the scientists quietly lose their shit.

dialogues.speaker: DETTWEILER
dialogues.text: Mein gott. Incredible. Igor looks to Victor, who raises an eyebrow: “Told you so

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, if you’d excuse us. The scientists move out into the lab. FINNEGAN (CONT’D) Well alright then, which one of you is going to be a sport and kill it?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- you- WHAT!? VICTOR-

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: What’s this tizzy? What do you want me to do? Bring it back? (tinkling laugh) Of course we have to kill the infant. I’m afraid this isn’t negotiable; I’d really be much more comfortable knowing the thing was properly disposed off.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It’s just an experiment, Igor. We must make sacrifices-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I won’t let you- I won’t stand by-  71.

dialogues.speaker: FINNEGAN
dialogues.text: My word, for the money I’m now going to put behind you, you can resurrect a dozen babies-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I- I- I- you bastard, you bloody monstrous bastard-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Now. Igor looks at the baby one last time, but his natural meekness overpowers him, and he storms out. INT. DETTWEILER’S LAB - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS Igor pushes through the scientists, making a beeline for door. EXT. DETTWEILER’S LAB - CONTINUOUS Igor storms out into the empty, snowy street, crying, rag he stomps back and forth. NO! HE WON’T STAND FOR THIS! INT. DETTWEILER’S LAB - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS Igor CHARGES back in, Finnegan stepping in front of him- shoves him aside, going towards the surggery door, which bursts open. Victor holds the dingy little bundle.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Make yourself useful and dispose of this. Victor slams the bundle to Igor’s chest. Igor stares at h in horror. Victor is emotionless, cold... The world seems to fall away for Igor. Everything goes silent. BEGIN SONG: “FIX

dialogues.speaker: COLDPLAY.
dialogues.text: Clutching the bundle to his chest, he turns and walks out door.  72. EXT. DETTWEILER’S LAB - CONTINUOUS Igor slams the door behind him, breathing hard, tears streaming down his face. He stares out into the predawn f his mind racing... The Baby Winthrop coos. Igor looks down: The baby, though unconscious, is alive. He blinks in shock. A scrap of pap is tucked in with the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scribbled in familiar handwriting: “I - How little you th of me. - F.” Igor let's out a little gasping laugh, and then looks aro in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow falls lightly, the crowd bustles, and Igor emerg carrying the baby. He walks across half the city, purposeful, not pausing; Christmas morning is peaceful, b we watch as the streets slowly crowd with people. We see him ask several strangers for directions, finding way, crossing bridges, going down alleys, finally reachin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor stops outside the house, and looks down at the baby. goes up to the door of the rickety little brownstone hous knocks, no reply. And then MR. WINTHROP answers the door; the man is a wrec pale, red-eyed, bereaved. He sees Igor; he speaks. Igor doesn’t respond. Instead, he simply holds out the baby. Winthrop stares at it, and then calls out, and again, and again. Igor hands the baby to him and he nearly faints. MRS. WINTHROP appears in the doorway. She sees the baby, and simply stares in shock. Mrs. Winth clutches onto both her child and her husband as Igor slow backs away from the door. The reunited family collapses i sobbing heap in their door frame. They begin to call after Igor, but Igor, taking one last look at them...vanishes into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor stands staring out over the water, crying, breathing hard, laughing and talking to himself. He seems to realiz something, and then takes off running.  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor runs, and runs, and runs, a man on fire. He stops, winded, to loosen his back brace. EXT. BARON BOMINE’S RESIDENCE - MOMENTS LATER Igor runs up from the street, through the garden, up to t front door, knocks frantically, waits, knocks again, wait the butler answers, Igor speaks frantically, the butler g away, Igor waits, tries to fix his disheveled appearance, makes it worse, Lorelei appears in the doorway- Igor grabs her and kisses her. After a startled moment, she kisses him back. They stand the doorway, laughing and holding each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor approaches, divinely happy, driven, heading towards door, when someone grabs his sleeve... ..-It’s Turpin. CuT “FIX YOU” ABRUPTLY.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Hello again, Igor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor is bringing out tea, his hands shaking. Turpin is settling down opposite Victor by the fire, Constable Alis over by the window. Victor now sits in the chair his father sat in, with Turp in the smaller seat.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Pleasant Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Indeed. We went caroling. We’re both very tired-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Whose coach was that I saw drop you off, Victor?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: My father’s. He took me for lunch. Turpin smiles.  74.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Igor, would you mind showing me your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Not just yet, Inspector. What's all this about?

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: It’s in relation to the Blue Meringue Circus Hunchback Murder.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What’s his shoe got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Interesting you said “shoe” rather than “shoes.” (beat) Something wrong, Mr. Straussman?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Oh! That’s right! I do recall reading about it: the hunchback what threw the dwarf off the bridge. (beat) Wasn’t there talk of...witchcraft?

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Well, we don’t give credence to occult speculation-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Not officially.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Oh, but unofficially? You believe in...witches, Inspector? Goblins?

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, nothing so extreme. But I do believe there are punishments for dealing with the devil. Just as there are punishments for lying to police officers. Victor and Turpin seem to lock in on each other.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, but police officers actually exist, you see.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Funny, Victor. But, in the end, things have a way of catching up, even with the funny people. Now let me see his shoes.  75.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: To see his shoes I’m afraid I’m going to have to see a proper search warrant.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: What’re you playing at Victor? What do you have to hide?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You've twice mentioned punishment without specifying who would be meting it out.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I inferred our Lord.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Oh yes, “God,” hm, well, I’m sure if god existed I would be in far deeper trouble than I am now-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I’m not here to convert you, Victor-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: No, indeed, go ahead, it’s a cause without a champion. Tell me more about this “god” fellow who apparently has some vendetta against me-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t come to debate religion with a child scientist-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What was the insult there, “child” or “scientist-"

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I know your bloody type, Frankenstein, all sure of their theories and analysis, you listen, my wife Claudia, bless her soul, she trusted in that poppycock and what'd it get her, dead, said it was appendicitis well look how far it got her knowing the name, how much money we spent on the medicines, my daughter crying all night, all the treatments and she’s still dead isn’t she, she’s still dead because God was punishing me wasn’t he, for my folly, and her for parlay with the gypsies come up from White Chapel, and you think you're so smart, well you’re not so smart and I’m onto you and I’1l-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: My god. You’re mad.  76. Turpin stops dead at this, trailing off and seeming to ta Victor’s accusation under very serious consideration.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Roderick, don’t-

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Easy constable. Don’t agitate the loony- Turpin flips the tea-tray, startling Igor, but Victor doe flinch. He stands there breathing hard for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I’1ll be back here with a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I look forward to that. Will you be bringing the apostles along as muscle?

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: We'll see. We’ll see who’s so bloody smart. Turpin goes to leave, but stops for a moment, taking a ha look at Igor, who’s frozen in terror. Turpin shakes his head, mutters something, and storms out, Alistair followi

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Well. That was exciting. The two of us both quite mad, shouting at each other. Stuff of legend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turpin rages out into the street, Alistair in tow.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: I want a damn warrant, call me mad-

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: INSPECTOR, I can’t vouch for you, we saw no sign of any foul play and the shoes alone aren’t enough-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Did you see how they froze up when we mentioned the shoes, they’re hiding something-

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: I agree that their behavior was suspicious, but-

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Sus- suspicious!? He arrived in a Finnegan Industries coach, and then lied! THEY LIED to my FACE. To our faces. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And coupled with Victor's combativeness, his aggression...And the basement door, open, Straussman staring at it in fear the whole time. A warrant isn’t good enough, we need a raid. Will you back me if we go to Chief Inspector?

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: -.-Yes. I will. There’s a strange beat, Turpin trying to collect himself.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: Listen, Alistair, I got excited in there but... (beat) I’m not mad. It comes out sounding more like a question than a stateme INT. VICTOR'S FLAT - VICTOR’S ROOM Victor is going through his closet, getting dressed, whil concerned Igor is nearby.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Did you have to needle him like that?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: The man was an unstable sideshow, of no threat to us-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: We had a saying back in the circus, “Never feed a lion when it’s hungry.”

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Enough. Victor pulls on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're already late for my hearing. Apparently they can’t expel me quickly enough. Victor seems to choke on this last sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, would you...come with me.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: To the hearing?  78.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yes. I intend to give them a piece of my mind and I'd rather- I'd rather not do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH TO
dialogues.text: Victor, silent and meek, on a raised platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful but very sparse, Victor standing alone ina sea of negative space, with the board of directors across room from him behind a desk. His father sits nearby, star out a window. Igor stands off to the side, in a corner. DR. CLIVE, the head of the board, old and dignified, is reading from a list.

dialogues.speaker: DR. CLIVE
dialogues.text: -students find Victor to be in turns rude, obnoxious, sinister, unpleasant, a loudmouth, a braggart, a false intellectual and a liar. For every essay Victor is assigned he returns spurious hokum regarding raising the dead, or rantings and blueprints regarding his apocryphal electrical creations. When reminded that this was not an engineering college, Victor was quoted as saying “The body is merely a machine. If you don’t understand this you are an ignorant nincompoop who is better off spending his day in a barn, perfecting the art of milking a male horse.” At this, there’s some hubbub at the board desk.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: D-...D- Doctor Clive, Doctor Cushing, Doctor Brannaugh, I j-

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRICE
dialogues.text: Dr. Frankenstein, have you anything to say? Frankenstein thinks.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: F- Father-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKENSTEIN
dialogues.text: Only that I am shocked that he was able to attend this long.  79.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRICE
dialogues.text: Very well. Victor Frankenstein, for the afore stated grievances,I hereby state that you are expelled from the Royal College of Medic-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: You leave him alone damn it!

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Igor, don’t-

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Has this reputable institution have no eye for real intelligence, real innovation, real revolution? Surely a real medical school would have this man performing his experiments in its hallowed halls, rather than in the dingy confines of a basement. Time will prove all of you fools, fools, and show this man to be a genius!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor looks to be in a state of shock. Igor’s flustered, breathing hard. The medical board exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PRICE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but...Who are you, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor and Igor sit in the coach as it rattles up the str Victor has his head pressed against the window, staring o Igor is clearly nervous he’s screwed up. Victor speaks without looking up, clearly lost in his own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: He wasn’t always like that you know. (beat) I had a brother. Henry. He was older than me by three years, but he never, he never bullied me the way the boys at schools were bullied by their brothers, he was...kind. He was intelligent, more than kind he was intelligent, my parents had such great hopes for him. One night, I went out in the snow, to watch a storm, I- I didn’t understand the danger, but Henry did. He came out looking for me, and Kent does get cold, it does get so cold at night. (shivers, upset) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I found my way home, but they found Henry the next morning....not Dead yet, but, dying. My father rushed to town to get medicine, but by the time he got back it was too late. Henry had...died. Only moments before my father returned. He was fourteen. (beat) It changed my father. Broke him. He lost hope in everything, became...you’ve seen him. You've seen what he became. And I suppose it changed me, too. I could no longer, like so many do, live in fear of death, in fear of life, these mystical things. No. I had to see them made tangible. Henry deserved a second chance. My father deserved a second chance, everyone deserves a second chance. And now I’ve built something that can finally... Victor trails off, staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you did back in the college. No one has ever. No one has ever. I have only ever had one friend. I am happy that it is you. Igor nods. Then, after a hesitant beat...

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Listen, Victor...I have faith in you. I have faith in your ideas, and I understand you think Finnegan is the only way to continue our work, but I ask you to reconsider. His motives are unclear, his lack of morality frightens me, and the fact that you’ve already given him most of your designs, our designs, scares me most of all. So if I truly am your partner...If I truly am your friend... Victor seems to osmose this for a moment, taking it in.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It’s all so dire now. All so dire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igor is nervously sketching out a design for a lightweigh collapsible wheelchair. He hears a sound from upstairs an waits, looking; it’s clear Victor has gone into his room not come out for some time. There’s a knock at the door.  81.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: (whisper-yell) Victor! Victor! Nothing. No response. Igor tries to look out the window, and can’t see anything. Tension builds. He goes and picks up a fireplace poker, then moves slowly to the door; the knock comes again, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (one last try) Victor! No response. Igor swings open the door and sees- LORELEI! Igor yelps, dropping the poker behind the door, then trying clumsily to camoflage his spazz-out by straightening his hair. One of Baron Bomine’s carriages is parked in the street behind her.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: (laughing) Did I scare you?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Yes, very much-

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: I thought since you were so bold in the morning, I should be bold tonight... (beat) Will you come with me to Baron Bomine’s Christmas ball? Igor looks hesitant; he glances back at Victor’s locked d at the top of the stairs, then at Lorelei, then back at t door, then Lorelei... INT. BARON BOMINE’S RESIDENCE - BANQUET ROOM Igor and Lorelei are at a long table, filled with rich an swanky looking high society types. Baron Bomine is seated nearby. A NOBLEMAN is talking animatedly his friends, Igo quietly listening and drinking.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Hospitals in general to me seem an indecent idea; piling the sick together like that, just seems against common logic. People go in with a broken leg, and come out dead from pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: S'not the hospitals.  82.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Beg pardon? Igor looks to Lorelei, horrified at having spoken up, but urges him on.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: A good modern hospital should never have these problems. It’s just that in a city of this size, many of the hospitals are unclean or poorly kept; the notion of a hospital is a positive one, it’s the execution, the lack of public support, the acceptance of under- qualified doctors and nurses that allows the sort of infective cross pollination you’re describing.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Mm. Probably quite right, I suppose; these days we seem to have wealth of medical students, and a dearth of real physicians. Are you a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I...I uh-

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: Yes, he was trained but never got a degree.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: I say, are you looking for a job? I run a company up north; it would be a real boon to have someone on staff who knows a bit about medicine, especially a respectable man like yourself.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: I...Uh, I would-

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: No need to give me an answer right away. I’11 look into it. What did you say your name was? Igor blanks out for a moment, shocked at the opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI
dialogues.text: Igor. Igor smiles excitedly at Lorelei, who squeezes his hand. LATER...  83. Igor is being introduced to various high society people; first, he looks nervous, but by the third intro, he’s laughing, smiling, cracking jokes... LATER... They're dancing; it’s all strict ballroom, but Igor and Lorelei are adding goofy little circus flourishes that ar drawing positive attention. Baron Bomine, watching on, lo pleased. Igor grunts, suddenly pained.

dialogues.speaker: LORELEI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Yes, I just need a minute. INT. BARON BOMINE’S RESIDENCE - IGOR AND LORELEI’S ROOM A frustrated Igor wrestles off his jacket and shirt. He t on the back-brace, finally fully taking it off. He realiz with a start that he’s fine without it; he’s outgrown it. Pondering this, folds up the brace into a pocket-size bal and stares at, rolling it around in his hand. It is Victo Lorelei enters, shutting the door behind her. Igor shows the folded back-brace. Lorelei turns and locks the door, then rushes Igor, tackl him; they fall onto the bed, giggling and making out...it slowly turns more sexy... INT. BOMINE CARRIAGE —- MORNING The carriage rumbles up the road, Igor happy in the backs clearly deep in thought. They turn onto Victor’s street, Igor looks up to see-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is SWARMING with cops. Bobbies are everywhere, pounding a battering ram against the front door, prying a the grates over the windows. Turpin’s among them.

dialogues.speaker: IGOR
dialogues.text: Go, go, up there. The carriage pulls around the corner, and Igor hops out, ducking immediately behind a fruit cart. The crowd is distracted by the bobbies, and Igor sneaks around, duckin through the crowd, trying to move towards an alley to the right of the house. Turpin’s head snaps up, pinpointing Igor’s quick movement the crowd.  84.

dialogues.speaker: TURPIN
dialogues.text: (mumbling) There you are. Turpin takes off running after Igor, Alistair staying beh with the bobbies. He runs hard, around the corner, around the building to t

dialogues.speaker: BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: Where he nearly catches Igor. The alley is cluttered with garbage, crates and water piping. Igor manages to snake through, vault over, or smash aside the obstructions; Tur can barely keep up. Without the back-brace, this clown can move. Igor rounds the corner, kicking a box of garbage into Turpin’s way, and then down a short, hidden set of stairs Victor's back door; Igor rushes through, slamming it in Victor's face. He screams in anger, kicking it and trying to get it open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
